definition: to quote out of context (idiom)
to break/to snap/to cut off/to give up or abstain from sth/to judge/(usu. used in the negative) absolutely/definitely/decidedly
chapter/section/clause/movement (of symphony)/seal/badge/regulation/order
surname Zhang
to take/to get/to choose/to fetch
justice/righteousness/meaning/foster (father etc)/adopted/artificial (tooth, limb etc)/relationship/friendship
surname Yi/(Tw) abbr. for 義大利|义大利[Yi4 da4 li4], Italy

sentences.english: Don't quote my words out of context.
sentences.chinese: 別斷章取義地引用我的話。

sentences.english: Yes, some of the comments have been taken out of context.
sentences.chinese: 完全正確，有些意見已經被斷章取義了。

sentences.english: His heart bled over certain phrases taken out of context.
sentences.chinese: 這幾句斷章取義的話好像很傷他的心。

sentences.english: Lets hope this scaremongering ceases before being hugely taken out of context.
sentences.chinese: 讓我們期待這之前，危言聳聽巨大斷章取義停止。

sentences.english: The words of Chen Qigang are used by the media out of context and are distorted.
sentences.chinese: 陳音樂總監的說法被媒體斷章取義了，或者說歪曲了。

sentences.english: The bag is untwisted and the bulb is taken out.
sentences.chinese: 袋子是未加撚和燈泡是斷章取義。

sentences.english: Publications glommed on to his findings and then distorted the data.
sentences.chinese: 出版物斷章取義，歪曲了他的數據。

sentences.english: Tom's statement was taken out of context and misinterpreted.
sentences.chinese: 湯姆的發言被斷章取義了，所以造成了誤解。

definition: lit. first impression is strongest
to spread falsehoods/to increasingly distort the truth/to pile errors on top of errors (idiom)
lit. to put Zhang's hat on Li's head/to attribute sth to the wrong person (idiom)/to confuse one thing with another
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
to confuse one thing with another (idiom); to muddle
misconception/fallacy
to start a rumor
to criticize (as a matter of principle)
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
lit. draw legs on a snake (idiom); fig. to ruin the effect by adding sth superfluous/to overdo it
arbitrary/subjective/dogmatic
to defame/to libel/to defile/to smear/to vilify
ambiguity/several possible meanings
to have an ulterior motive (idiom)
frightening words to scare people (idiom); alarmist talk/reds under the beds
